Description: The painters of "istoriato" maiolica did not always get their literary sources right. This painting shows the story of the maiden Europa, who was abducted by the amorous king of the gods Jupiter in the form of a bull and carried across the sea. The story is told by the poet Ovid in "The Metamorphoses," Book II, but the inscription on the reverse of the plate indicates that it was taken from Book III. The painter narrates the whole story by depicting the main figures several times within a single scene.

Inscriptions: [Inscription] On the back center, in blue: 1533 / De gioue ede eropa / Nel • iii libro de Ouidio •M•h• / in urbino: ; decorative floral motif in lustre overtop of ‘in urbino’
Medium: earthenware with tin glaze (maiolica) and luster decoration

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Third Floor: Renaissance Ceramics

Provenance: H. Wencke Collection, Hamburg [date and mode of acquisition unknown] (?); Seligmann [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, May 7, 1908, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Plate with the Abduction of Europa
